name: Mars

descriptions.short: Mars is called the Red Planet because of the rusty iron in its soil. It's cold and dusty!
descriptions.medium: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun and the second smallest planet in our solar system. It has two small moons and is known for its red color caused by iron oxide (rust) on its surface.
descriptions.long: Mars is a cold desert world with a thin atmosphere composed primarily of carbon dioxide. It has the largest volcano in the solar system (Olympus Mons) and a massive canyon system (Valles Marineris). Evidence suggests Mars once had liquid water on its surface and may have been warmer and wetter in the past. Today, water exists as ice at the poles and possibly as liquid brine beneath the surface. Mars experiences seasons due to its axial tilt, and massive dust storms can envelope the entire planet.

funFacts: A day on Mars is almost the same as a day on Earth - just 37 minutes longer!
Mars has the largest volcano in the solar system - Olympus Mons, which is 21 km high
Mars has two small moons named after the sons of the Roman god of war
Pieces of Mars have fallen to Earth as meteorites
Mars has seasons like Earth because of its tilted axis
The red color comes from iron oxide (rust) in the Martian soil

atmosphere.description: Mars has a thin atmosphere, about 100 times thinner than Earth's. It's not thick enough to retain heat or protect the surface from radiation. The thin atmosphere causes extreme temperature variations between day and night.

features.name: Olympus Mons
features.description: The largest volcano in the solar system, standing 21 km high and 600 km wide
features.significance: Nearly three times the height of Mount Everest

features.name: Valles Marineris
features.description: A massive canyon system stretching over 4,000 km long, 200 km wide, and up to 7 km deep
features.significance: Would span the entire United States from coast to coast

features.name: Polar Ice Caps
features.description: Permanent ice caps made of water ice and frozen carbon dioxide
features.significance: Contain enough water ice to cover the planet in 35 meters of water if melted

features.name: Jezero Crater
features.description: A 45 km wide crater that once contained a lake and river delta
features.significance: Current location of NASA's Perseverance rover, searching for signs of ancient life

surface.terrain: Rocky desert with canyons, volcanoes, dry lake beds, and impact craters

majorMoons.name: Phobos
majorMoons.description: The larger and inner moon of Mars, Phobos is slowly spiraling toward Mars and will either crash into the planet or break apart into a ring in about 50 million years. It's heavily cratered and irregularly shaped.
majorMoons.mythology: Named after Phobos (fear), son of Ares (Mars) in Greek mythology
majorMoons.features: Spiraling toward Mars, heavily cratered, irregular shape, Stickney crater

majorMoons.name: Deimos
majorMoons.description: The smaller and outer moon of Mars, Deimos has a smoother surface than Phobos, covered in fine regolith. It's slowly moving away from Mars.
majorMoons.mythology: Named after Deimos (terror), son of Ares (Mars) in Greek mythology
majorMoons.features: Moving away from Mars, smoother surface, small and irregular

roman.namedAfter: Mars, the Roman god of war
roman.origin: The planet's blood-red color reminded ancient Romans of battlefields, making it a fitting tribute to their war god
roman.story: Mars was the Roman god of war, representing combat, violence, and military power. He was one of the most important gods in Roman religion and was considered the father of Romulus and Remus, the legendary founders of Rome. Unlike his Greek counterpart Ares, who was often portrayed negatively, Mars was highly respected and seen as a guardian of Rome.
roman.culturalSignificance: Mars was second only to Jupiter in importance in Roman religion. The month of March (Martius) is named after him, as it was traditionally the beginning of the military campaign season. Warriors would pray to Mars before battle, and he was honored with festivals and games.
roman.symbolism: War, military power, agriculture (in early Roman religion), masculinity, courage

indian.meaning: Mangala means 'auspicious' in Sanskrit; Angaraka means 'burning coal' or 'red one'; Kuja means 'born from Earth'
indian.origin: In Hindu tradition, Mars is personified as Mangala, a deity associated with strength, courage, and martial energy
indian.birthStory: According to Hindu mythology, Mangala was born from the sweat or blood of Lord Shiva when it fell upon the Earth. Another tradition states he is the son of Bhudevi (Mother Earth), hence the name Kuja (born from Earth).
indian.characteristics: Mangala is depicted as a warrior deity with red complexion, riding a ram or chariot pulled by eight red horses. He carries weapons including a trident, mace, and spear, symbolizing his martial nature.
indian.role: Mangala is one of the Navagraha (nine celestial deities) in Hindu astrology and is considered the commander of celestial armies. He governs courage, strength, vitality, aggression, and determination.
indian.astrologicalSignificance: In Vedic astrology, Mangala rules the zodiac signs Aries (Mesha) and Scorpio (Vrishchika). He represents energy, action, ambition, passion, and physical strength. Mars is considered both a benefic and malefic planet depending on its placement.
indian.culturalSignificance: Tuesday (Mangalvar in Hindi) is dedicated to Mangala. Devotees worship him for courage, success in endeavors, protection from enemies, and to mitigate negative astrological effects. Red is his associated color, and red lentils, red flowers, and jaggery are offered in worship.
indian.symbolism: Courage, strength, determination, martial prowess, energy, passion, aggression, discipline, real estate and property (in astrology)

chinese.name: 火星 (Huǒxīng)
chinese.origin: In Chinese astronomy and astrology, Mars is called Huoxing, literally meaning 'Fire Star', due to its red color
chinese.element: Fire (Huo) - one of the Five Elements (Wu Xing)
chinese.characteristics: Mars represents the Fire element in Chinese cosmology, associated with summer, heat, growth, and transformation. It embodies yang energy - active, dynamic, and expansive.
chinese.astrologicalSignificance: In Chinese astrology, Mars governs passion, aggression, conflict, and rapid change. It influences military affairs, accidents, fires, and sudden events. Mars transits are watched carefully for their impact on warfare and social unrest.
chinese.culturalSignificance: Mars is one of the Five Planets (Wu Xing) that correspond to the Five Elements. Ancient Chinese astronomers carefully tracked Mars' movements, believing its position and brightness could predict wars, droughts, and political upheaval.
chinese.symbolism: Fire, yang energy, summer, passion, conflict, transformation, military matters

babylonian.name: Nergal
babylonian.origin: In ancient Babylonian and Mesopotamian astronomy, Mars was associated with Nergal, a major deity of the underworld
babylonian.characteristics: Nergal was a complex deity representing war, plague, death, and the scorching heat of the sun. He was depicted as a fierce warrior and was both feared and respected.
babylonian.story: Nergal was the husband of Ereshkigal, queen of the underworld. According to myth, he descended to the underworld and became its co-ruler. He commanded demons and was invoked in times of war and pestilence.
babylonian.astrologicalSignificance: The Babylonians were among the first to systematically observe and record Mars' movements. They associated Mars with warfare, destruction, and disease. Mars' retrograde motion was considered particularly ominous.
babylonian.culturalSignificance: Babylonian astronomers tracked Mars with great precision, creating detailed astronomical diaries. Their observations of Mars influenced later Greek and Roman astronomy. The association of Mars with war and calamity originated in Mesopotamian tradition.
babylonian.symbolism: War, plague, death, underworld, destruction, scorching heat

egyptian.name: Har Decher (Horus the Red)
egyptian.origin: Ancient Egyptians associated Mars with Horus in his red aspect, or sometimes with Set, the god of chaos and the desert
egyptian.characteristics: Mars was called 'Horus the Red' or 'The Red Horus' due to its distinctive color. Some traditions associated it with Set, the god of storms, disorder, and violence, because of its reddish hue and erratic motion.
egyptian.dualAssociation: The planet's association varied between Horus (representing order and kingship) and Set (representing chaos and the desert). This duality reflected Mars' unpredictable movements and its blood-red color.
egyptian.astrologicalSignificance: Egyptian astronomers observed Mars as part of their celestial observations, though their records are less detailed than Babylonian ones. Mars was considered a powerful celestial force that could influence earthly events.
egyptian.culturalSignificance: Mars' retrograde motion and varying brightness were noted by Egyptian priests and astronomers. The planet's red color connected it to the red desert lands ruled by Set, as well as to blood and warfare.
egyptian.symbolism: War, chaos, desert, blood, royal power (as Horus), disorder (as Set)

norse.name: Tyr's Star
norse.namedAfter: Tyr (Týr), the Norse god of war, law, and justice
norse.origin: In Norse and Germanic traditions, Tuesday (Tyr's day) is named after Tyr, connecting the day to Mars just as the Roman 'Dies Martis' (Mars' day) became Tuesday in Romance languages
norse.characteristics: Tyr was a one-handed god who sacrificed his hand to bind the wolf Fenrir. He represented courage, honor, justice, and self-sacrifice in warfare. Unlike the Roman Mars, Tyr embodied lawful warfare and oaths.
norse.story: Tyr was one of the oldest Germanic gods, associated with the sky and war. His most famous myth involves binding Fenrir: to restrain the monstrous wolf, Tyr placed his hand in Fenrir's mouth as a pledge of good faith. When the gods bound Fenrir with magical chains, the wolf bit off Tyr's hand. This sacrifice made Tyr a symbol of courage and honor.
norse.culturalSignificance: Tuesday is named after Tyr in English and Germanic languages (Tuesday = Tyr's day), paralleling the Roman naming of the day after Mars (Mardi in French, Martes in Spanish). This linguistic connection links Mars to Tyr across cultures.
norse.symbolism: War, justice, law, courage, honor, oaths, self-sacrifice, victory in battle
norse.rune: Tiwaz (ᛏ) - the rune associated with Tyr, representing justice and sacrifice

formation.description: Mars formed about 4.6 billion years ago from the solar nebula. It's smaller than Earth because it formed in a region with less material available. Early Mars likely had a thicker atmosphere and liquid water on its surface, but lost most of its atmosphere over billions of years due to its weak magnetic field and low gravity.

history.geologicalHistory: Noachian Period (4.1 to 3.7 billion years ago): Heavy bombardment by asteroids, formation of large impact basins, possible presence of liquid water and a thicker atmosphere Hesperian Period (3.7 to 3.0 billion years ago): Widespread volcanic activity, formation of large lava plains, gradual loss of atmosphere Amazonian Period (3.0 billion years ago to present): Cold, dry conditions similar to today, occasional volcanic activity, ongoing atmospheric loss
history.waterHistory: Evidence suggests Mars once had rivers, lakes, and possibly oceans. Ancient riverbeds, deltas, and minerals that form in water have been discovered. Most of this water was lost to space or frozen underground. Today, water exists as ice at the poles and possibly as liquid brine beneath the surface.

missions.name: Perseverance
primaryObjectives: Search for signs of ancient microbial life
Collect rock and soil samples for potential return to Earth
Test oxygen production from Martian atmosphere (MOXIE experiment)
missions.description: Perseverance is NASA's most advanced Mars rover, equipped with 7 scientific instruments and 23 cameras. It's exploring Jezero Crater, which scientists believe was once filled with water and may contain signs of ancient life.
majorAchievements: Successfully landed in Jezero Crater on February 18, 2021
Deployed Ingenuity helicopter, the first aircraft to fly on another planet
Ingenuity completed over 70 flights, far exceeding its original 5-flight mission
Collected over 20 rock and soil samples sealed in tubes for future return to Earth
Produced oxygen from Mars atmosphere using MOXIE experiment
Discovered evidence of ancient river delta and lake in Jezero Crater
Found organic molecules in ancient rocks
Recorded sounds of Mars, including wind and rover operations
instruments: SuperCam: Laser and camera for analyzing rocks
SHERLOC: UV spectrometer for detecting organic compounds

companion.name: Ingenuity
companion.description: A 1.8 kg autonomous helicopter that demonstrated powered flight is possible in Mars' thin atmosphere

missions.name: Curiosity
primaryObjectives: Determine if Mars ever had conditions suitable for microbial life
missions.description: Curiosity is a car-sized rover exploring Gale Crater and Mount Sharp. It's been operating for over 11 years, far exceeding its original 2-year mission.
majorAchievements: Successfully landed using innovative 'sky crane' system on August 6, 2012
Confirmed Mars once had conditions suitable for microbial life
Discovered organic molecules in 3.5 billion-year-old rocks
Detected methane in the atmosphere, which varies seasonally
Studied radiation levels to help plan human missions
Climbed Mount Sharp, studying different geological layers
Traveled over 30 km on Mars surface
Still operating after 11+ years, far exceeding design life
instruments: SAM: Sample Analysis at Mars (detects organic compounds)

missions.name: InSight
missions.fullName: Interior Exploration using Seismic Investigations, Geodesy and Heat Transport
missions.description: InSight was the first mission dedicated to studying Mars' deep interior. It operated for 4 years before dust accumulation on its solar panels ended the mission.
majorAchievements: Detected over 1,300 marsquakes
Determined Mars has a liquid core
Measured the thickness of Mars crust
Studied Mars magnetic field
Recorded sounds of Martian wind and marsquakes
Provided data on Mars interior structure and composition

missions.name: Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter
missions.description: MRO has been studying Mars from orbit for over 17 years, providing high-resolution images and data about Mars surface and atmosphere.
majorAchievements: Discovered evidence of flowing liquid water on present-day Mars
Mapped Mars surface in unprecedented detail
Served as communication relay for Mars rovers
Studied Mars climate and seasonal changes
Transmitted over 400 terabits of data

marsSampleReturn.description: Joint NASA-ESA mission to return samples collected by Perseverance to Earth
marsSampleReturn.significance: Would be the first samples returned from Mars

humanMission.description: NASA's Artemis program aims to send humans to Mars
challenges: In-situ resource utilization (producing fuel and oxygen on Mars)

habitability.pastHabitability: Mars likely had conditions suitable for life 3-4 billion years ago, with liquid water, a thicker atmosphere, and warmer temperatures
habitability.currentConditions: Harsh environment with thin atmosphere, extreme cold, high radiation, and no liquid water on surface
habitability.potentialForLife: Possible subsurface habitats where liquid water may exist as brine, protected from radiation
habitability.biosignatures: Perseverance and Curiosity have found organic molecules, but no definitive evidence of past or present life

comparisonToEarth.size: About half the diameter of Earth
comparisonToEarth.gravity: 38% of Earth's gravity (you'd weigh much less)
comparisonToEarth.yearLength: Nearly twice as long as Earth (687 days)
comparisonToEarth.water: No liquid water on surface (Earth has abundant liquid water)

interestingFacts.sunsets: Sunsets on Mars appear blue due to dust in the atmosphere scattering light differently than on Earth
interestingFacts.seasons: Mars has seasons like Earth, but they last twice as long
interestingFacts.dustStorms: Mars can have dust storms that cover the entire planet and last for months
interestingFacts.tallestMountain: Olympus Mons is the tallest mountain in the solar system
interestingFacts.longestCanyon: Valles Marineris would stretch across the entire United States
interestingFacts.meteorites: We have over 200 Martian meteorites on Earth that were blasted off Mars by asteroid impacts
interestingFacts.namesake: Mars is the only planet named after a god of war rather than a supreme deity
